questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 5-day history of sore throat and a painful swelling on the left side of his neck that has become progressively larger. He has had pain during swallowing and has refused to eat solid foods for the past 3 days. He immigrated to the United States one year ago from India. His immunization records are unavailable. His family keeps 2 cats as pets. He appears well. He is at the 60th percentile for height and 50th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 103/min, and blood pressure is 92/60 mm Hg. The oropharynx is erythematous; the tonsils are enlarged with exudates. There is a 3-cm warm, tender, nonfluctuant cervical lymph node on the left side of the neck.  His hemoglobin is 12.6 g/dL, leukocyte count is 11,100/mm3, and platelet count is 180,000/mm3. In addition to obtaining a throat swab and culture, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine are drugs used for the treatment of toxoplasmosis. The transmission of toxoplasmosis may occur after ingestion of Toxoplasma cysts found, e.g., in contaminated raw meat or cat feces. Although toxoplasmosis may cause cervical tender lymphadenopathy, it is usually bilateral as opposed to unilateral. Additionally, toxoplasmosis does usually not cause leukocytosis. Also, if toxoplasmosis were suspected, serologic testing would be indicated before initiating treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Incision and drainage are indicated in patients with unilateral cervical lymphadenitis and severe symptoms (e.g., ill-appearance, tender/warm lymphadenitis with fluctuance or cellulitis). However, this patient does not have severe symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Fine-needle aspiration biopsy is part of the workup for conditions such as primary neck tumors, congenital neck masses, and chronic lymphadenopathy. It may also be performed in acute cases of unilateral lymphadenitis with moderate symptoms (e.g., warmth or fever), if the inflamed lymph node is suppurative, exudative tonsillopharyngitis is not present, or there is not an adequate response to antibiotic therapy. However, this patient presents with tonsillar exudates (and a throat swab has already been obtained), he has not yet been treated, and he does not have any of the remaining conditions requiring fine-needle aspiration biopsy.

D) CORRECT:

Clindamycin is used for the treatment of several bacterial infections, including acute unilateral pyogenic lymphadenitis. This infection is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pyogenes, or oral anaerobes and is characterized by painful unilateral cervical swelling. While patients with minimal symptoms don't always require laboratory diagnostics or treatment, patients with moderate symptoms (i.e., fever, tender/warm lymphadenitis without fluctuance), such as this boy, should undergo laboratory evaluation and empiric antibiotic treatment.

The most likely cause of this patient's lymphadenitis is tonsillopharyngitis, given the history of sore throat and odynophagia, as well as the exam findings of erythematous, swollen, tonsils with exudates. Microbiological specimens should be obtained prior to starting empiric antibiotic therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

Tuberculin skin testing is used to diagnose exposure to Mycobacterium tuberculosis. This patient immigrated from India, a country with a very high incidence of TB, which puts him at increased risk of contracting TB. While TB may manifest with a localized swelling in the cervical region, TB-associated lymphadenitis is usually nontender and typically presents subacutely or chronically. Also, this patient has no other symptoms of TB (e.g., fever, weight loss, or productive cough). In this patient with acute unilateral lymphadenitis, tuberculin skin testing is not indicated at this time.

F) INCORRECT:

Immunoglobulin therapy is used for the treatment of Kawasaki disease (KD). KD may cause unilateral, tender cervical lymphadenopathy, but this patient does not show evidence of systemic inflammation (e.g., fever, ill appearance) or other signs that would raise suspicion of KD, e.g., conjunctivitis, oropharyngeal mucositis (e.g., cracked and red lips, glossitis), or rash.

G) INCORRECT:

An excisional biopsy is indicated in patients with cervical lymph node enlargement and suspected malignancy (e.g., patients with constitutional symptoms and/or nontender, hard, progressive lymphadenopathy). If the initial diagnostic workup is negative or mycobacterial lymphadenitis is suspected, excisional biopsy is also recommended in patients with subacute/chronic unilateral cervical lymph node enlargement. This patient has no constitutional symptoms and has acute, tender lymphadenopathy. While his history of immigration puts him at risk of contracting TB, he has no other symptoms of an infection with Mycobacterium tuberculosis (e.g., fever, weight loss, productive cough).

H) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and a follow-up in 2 weeks would be an appropriate recommendation for a patient with acute bilateral cervical lymphadenitis, which is usually caused by a self-limiting viral infection, or a patient with acute unilateral lymphadenitis with only minimal symptoms (i.e., no fever, slightly enlarged lymphadenitis with only minimal tenderness). This patient has warm, tender, unilateral cervical lymphadenitis and leukocytosis and therefore requires a different approach.
questions.hint: The patient has acute unilateral cervical lymphadenitis, which is most commonly caused by a bacterial infection.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of swollen neck glands for the past 2 days. One week ago, she had a 4-day episode of cough and a runny nose. She currently feels well. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. Immunizations are up-to-date. The girl appears well. She is at the 50th percentile for height and the 60th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows multiple, enlarged, slightly tender, mobile lymph nodes measuring 1.5–2 cm in diameter on both sides of the anterior neck. There is no warmth or erythema of the skin overlying these lymph nodes. There is mild pharyngeal erythema. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management at this time?

choices.text: Perform an excisional lymph node biopsy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Empiric antibiotic therapy should be initiated in patients with acute unilateral cervical lymphadenitis (UCL) and moderate symptoms (e.g., warm, tender adenitis, fever). While the most common cause of acute UCL is Staphylococcus aureus, any suspicion of GAS tonsillopharyngitis (e.g., fever, exudative pharyngitis) warrants antibiotic treatment. The most likely etiology in this well-appearing, afebrile child with bilateral lymphadenopathy is viral, for which antibiotics are ineffective.

B) CORRECT:

Acute BCL, which is most commonly caused by viral upper respiratory tract infections, is typically self-limiting. Active observation and reassurance is therefore indicated for well-appearing patients with mild BCL and no features of GAS tonsillitis. Indications for further diagnostic workup include: an ill-appearing patient, features suggestive of bacterial infection (e.g., unilateral large, tender lymph nodes, purulent discharge), constitutional symptoms, certain exposures (e.g., ill-contacts, unpasteurized animal milk ingestion, animal exposures, a recent travel history), and progression of symptoms or lack of regression within 1 month. A variety of tests may be indicated depending on the patient's history, risk of exposure, and physical exam and may include laboratory studies, blood cultures, throat swab and culture, tuberculin skin test, ultrasound, or CT scan.

C) INCORRECT:

An excisional lymph node biopsy with histopathology is indicated in patients with cervical lymphadenitis and features that raise concern for malignancy (e.g., nontender, hard, progressively enlarging lymph nodes, constitutional symptoms, blasts on complete blood count), tuberculosis (e.g., positive tuberculins skin test), or persistent (> 6–8 weeks) and progressive symptoms of undetermined cause. However, because this patient lacks the aforementioned features and is afebrile, well-appearing, and has small, mobile lymph nodes with a preceding viral illness, a lymph node biopsy is not indicated at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

Throat swabbing for a rapid antigen test or bacterial culture is performed to confirm group A streptococcus (GAS) tonsillopharyngitis. Throat swabs should not be performed without strong clinical suspicion of GAS infection because GAS often colonizes the oropharynx without causing any infection. In a child presenting with acute BCL, throat swabs are unnecessary if there is a history of recent cough and coryza; the presence of both makes a viral URTI likely and GAS extremely unlikely. In children with acute BCL and no history of viral URTI symptoms, a throat swab is performed if any of the following features are present: concomitant fever > 38°C, tonsillar swelling, pharyngeal or tonsillar exudates, evidence of suppurative lymphadenitis (e.g., severe tenderness, fluctuating swelling). Mild pharyngeal erythema and slight lymph node tenderness are common with viral URTIs and these findings alone are not indications for performing a throat swab.

E) INCORRECT:

Laboratory testing including a CBC is indicated in patients with acute BCL who are febrile and/or ill-appearing or in those who have severe, progressive, or persistent illness. A CBC can provide information about infectious etiologies, bone marrow function, and systemic involvement and abnormal results may prompt additional evaluation (e.g., a bone marrow biopsy if peripheral cytopenias appear on CBC). Because this patient appears well and has only had mild symptoms in conjunction with a short history of cervical lymphadenitis, laboratory testing is not indicated at this time.
questions.hint: This well-appearing patient has a 2-day history of bilateral, cervical lymph node enlargement, which is consistent with acute bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy (BCL). The history of recent upper respiratory tract infection (URTI) suggests a viral etiology.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man with no significant medical history presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of “swollen glands” in his neck for the past 2 to 3 weeks. He first noticed a swollen bump on the right side of his neck but then gradually found other lumps in his neck. He has had a dry cough with intermittent fevers of 38.3°C to 38.9°C. He has had trouble sleeping comfortably because of sweating and difficulty breathing, and he reports being more tired than usual.
He is completing a 10-day course of amoxicillin-clavulanate today after testing negative for Epstein-Barr virus (negative titers).
On physical examination, he is sitting with a temperature of 38.0°C, a heart rate of 85 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, a blood pressure of 119/76 mm Hg, and an oxygen saturation of 99% while breathing ambient air. He weighs 62.4 kg, but at his annual visit 5 months ago, he weighed 70 kg. He is awake and alert but pale. His ear-nose-throat examination is normal except for mild pharyngeal erythema.
He has diffuse anterior and posterior cervical lymphadenopathy bilaterally that is confluent with the largest group of lymph nodes measuring 3 cm x 2 cm. There is no overlying erythema, and on palpation, the nodes are neither tender nor warm to the touch. His lungs are clear to auscultation, and he has no retractions or increased work of breathing. His abdominal examination reveals splenomegaly. The rest of the examination is normal.
A complete blood count is normal.
What is the most appropriate immediate next step in evaluating this patient?

choices.text: CT of the chest with contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An interferon gamma-release assay is used to assess for tuberculosis. Although tuberculous lymphadenitis is in the differential diagnosis for this patient, it is typically unilateral and thus less likely than lymphoma in this case.

B) INCORRECT:

Most patients with cat-scratch disease due to Bartonella henselae have localized adenopathy, and splenomegaly is rare. Although Bartonella infection is in the differential diagnosis for this patient, evaluating for a mediastinal mass should take precedence.

C) CORRECT:

This patient’s presentation — gradually progressive adenopathy and splenomegaly along with systemic symptoms including fatigue and the “B” symptoms fever, night sweats, and weight loss — is concerning for lymphoma, especially since infection with Epstein-Barr virus has already been excluded.

Patients with lymphoma are at risk for developing a rapidly enlarging mediastinal mass with airway obstruction, which is a particular concern in this patient given his difficulty breathing when lying flat to sleep at night and his tachypnea on examination. Therefore, the most appropriate next step for this patient is a chest radiograph to urgently assess for an intrathoracic mass and evidence of airway obstruction. Depending on the findings, immediate interventions to secure the airway may be needed.

Eventually, this patient will need CT of the neck, chest, abdomen and pelvis, or integrated positron emission tomography and CT (PET-CT), as well as a biopsy of an accessible mass. However, CT and PET-CT would not constitute first-line imaging in a patient in whom malignant airway obstruction is suspected. A chest radiograph is the best and safest immediate choice in this case as it is faster, can be done with the patient sitting upright, and will guide immediate management.

Key learning point: A patient with likely lymphoma presenting with progressive cervical adenopathy should be urgently evaluated with a chest radiograph.

D) INCORRECT:

Peripheral blood flow cytometry may identify abnormal populations of cells and suggest a diagnosis, but normal flow cytometry results are not adequate to exclude a diagnosis of lymphoma, which requires excisional or core biopsy of affected lymph nodes. In some high-grade lymphomas, such as diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, the cells are fragile and shear as they are processed through the flow cytometer, leading to negative flow panel results.

E) INCORRECT:

Eventually, this patient will need CT of the neck, chest, abdomen and pelvis, or integrated positron emission tomography and CT (PET-CT), as well as a biopsy of an accessible mass. However, CT and PET-CT would not constitute first-line imaging in a patient in whom malignant airway obstruction is suspected. A chest radiograph is the best and safest immediate choice in this case as it is faster, can be done with the patient sitting upright, and will guide immediate management.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old girl presents with a left-sided neck mass that is draining to the skin and that has persisted despite a 2-week course of clindamycin. She has a cat at home and no history of recent travel.
She appears well and has a temperature of 37.2°C and a heart rate of 86 beats per minute. Her other vital signs are normal. The neck mass is 2 cm by 3 cm and nontender. The overlying skin is purple in color, and there is a fistula present. No fluctuance is noted. No other lymphadenopathy is seen on examination, and there is no hepatosplenomegaly.
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Submit an aspirate of the lesion for pathologic evaluation
Refer for surgical evaluation and excision of the lesion
Order serologic testing for Epstein-Barr virus

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fine-needle aspiration (FNA) is generally not recommended for initial workup of lymphadenopathy. Histologic architecture can be lost with FNA samples. In addition, there is risk of tract formation in cases such as mycobacterial infection and false negative findings if the wrong node is sampled.

B) INCORRECT:

Bartonella henselae titers are used to evaluate for cat-scratch disease. Although this patient's lymphadenitis could be a manifestation of cat-scratch disease, B. henselae titers are not as specific as microbiologic and pathologic examination, and a definitive diagnostic (and in this case, therapeutic) procedure is preferred.

C) CORRECT:

Acute cervical lymphadenopathy is common in children and is typically caused by infection. The most common bacterial causes are group A beta-hemolytic streptococci and Staphylococcus aureus. Initial therapy, such as cephalexin or clindamycin, is usually directed at these organisms. When patients do not improve on this therapy, a variety of situations need to be considered, including antibiotic resistance, abscess formation, other infections, or oncologic causes. Cancer-associated lymphadenopathy is characteristically hard and fixed to underlying tissues, and it does not drain to the skin, as the lymphadenopathy in this case does.

This patient's nontender lymph node with violaceous overlying skin and fistula formation is concerning for atypical mycobacterium infection. These infections are treated with complete surgical excision.

Key learning point: The most likely class of organisms to cause nontender cervical lymphadenopathy that is unresponsive to antibiotics and results in fistula formation is atypical mycobacteria.

D) INCORRECT:

The presentation of a single draining cervical lymph node is not consistent with primary infection with Epstein-Barr virus, which, when symptomatic, manifests with more generalized cervical lymphadenopathy.

E) INCORRECT:

Initiation of intravenous vancomycin would be indicated if the patient had acute bacterial cervical lymphadenitis caused by a pathogen resistant to clindamycin. However, this patient's clinical picture is not consistent with a typical bacterial cervical lymphadenitis: Acute bacterial lymphadenitis is characterized by erythema, fluctuance, and tenderness of the involved lymph node. Patients are frequently febrile when the lymphadenitis is caused by an acute bacterial process.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old girl presents for evaluation of a mass in her neck that her mother first noticed 4 weeks ago. Two weeks ago, she was seen for the mass at an urgent care clinic and was treated with 2 weeks of oral clindamycin, without improvement. The mother reports that the mass continues to grow in size and that the skin over the mass is now reddish-blue in color.
The patient has been feeling well, has not had any recent upper respiratory symptoms, and has no constitutional symptoms. She has no history of travel or exposure to animals.
On physical examination, she appears well and has a temperature of 37.7°C and a normal blood pressure. A nontender, 3-cm submandibular lymph node, with an overlying violaceous appearance to the skin, is palpable on the left side. There is no other cervical lymphadenopathy, and the remainder of the examination is normal.
A complete blood count and erythrocyte sedimentation rate are normal.
Which one of the following interventions is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Incision and drainage of the mass

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous vancomycin may be used to treat skin and soft-tissue infections caused by Staphylococcus aureus, particularly methicillin-resistant S. aureus. However, this patient's presentation is more subacute with no significant systemic symptoms, the infection has been unresponsive to oral antibiotic therapy, and the patient's complete blood count and erythrocyte sedimentation rate are both normal.

B) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin can be used for the treatment of cervical lymphadenitis caused by infection with Bartonella henselae (cat-scratch disease). Patients with such infection may have a history of cutaneous findings (e.g., a papulur lesion) at the site of inoculation and a history of exposure to cats or, more commonly, kittens.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's cervical lymphadenitis is most likely caused by nontuberculous mycobacteria (NTM). Although pulmonary infections are the most typical presentation of NTM infection in older patients and those with chronic lung disease, the most common presentation in young healthy children is cervical lymphadenitis.

Children with lymphadenitis caused by NTM typically present subacutely with a history of a neck mass that has been enlarging over the course of several weeks. In many cases, the children have been treated with antibiotics for suspected bacterial lymphadenitis, without response. On examination, the skin overlying the lymph node typically has a violaceous appearance. Although the neck mass may be tender, it is not usually as painful and acutely tender as a bacterial abscess. The cervicofacial area is most commonly involved, and the submandibular location is classic for nontuberculous lymphadenitis. Potential complications include fistulas and sinus tract formation.

The treatment of choice for cervical lymphadenitis caused by NTM is surgical excision rather than incision and drainage, which can result in the formation of a fistulous tract.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial management for a patient with cervical lymphadenitis due to nontuberculous mycobacteria is surgical excision.

D) INCORRECT:

Observation alone is not appropriate for a patient with a mass that has continued to grow over several weeks and that has new skin-color changes.

E) INCORRECT:

Incision and drainage is indicated for a suspected bacterial abscess, but that diagnosis is less likely in this case, given that the patient's lymphadenitis is nontender, it has not caused significant local or systemic symptoms despite being present for 4 weeks, and the complete blood count and erythrocyte sedimentation rate are normal.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old girl presents for follow-up of cervical lymphadenopathy. She was initially evaluated 14 days ago for a mildly tender, 2-cm left cervical lymph node that had been progressively enlarging for 10 days. She was treated for presumed bacterial lymphadenitis with a 14-day course of oral amoxicillin-clavulanate on initial presentation.
Despite the antibiotic treatment, her cervical lymphadenopathy has progressed, and she now has a 3-cm x 4-cm mass that is palpable in the anterior cervical lymph-node chain. There is no significant tenderness to palpation, no overlying erythema or fluctuance, and no other enlarged lymph nodes. The patient has had no fever, weight loss, or chills.
A purified protein derivative (PPD) skin test is negative, as is serologic testing for cat-scratch disease.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in this patient’s care?

choices.text: Perform fine-needle aspiration of the lymph node

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin could be considered if there was concern for Bartonella infection, and it can also be part of a treatment regimen for proven atypical mycobacterial infections, but biopsy is indicated for diagnostic clarity before additional antibiotic treatment is initiated.

B) CORRECT:

Lymphadenopathy that is unresponsive to 14 days of antibiotic therapy warrants further evaluation with biopsy. The differential diagnosis in this case includes mycobacterial infection (both tuberculosis and atypical mycobacterial infection), Bartonella infection (cat-scratch disease), and malignancy. Typically, the preferred approach is to perform fine-needle aspiration (FNA) of the lymph node for microbiological evaluation. An excisional biopsy is also an option and has greater sensitivity, particularly when malignancy is high on the differential, but it requires general anesthesia and so presents more risk to the patient. FNA as an initial diagnostic test is the reasonable next step in a child who can undergo this procedure with local anesthesia.

Key learning point: The most appropriate diagnostic strategy for evaluating a school-age child who has unexplained lymphadenopathy that is unresponsive to a course of antibiotics and who has negative results on both a purified protein derivative test and serologic testing for cat-scratch disease is fine-needle aspiration of the lymph node.

C) INCORRECT:

A 5-day course of prednisone would not be appropriate at this time because glucocorticoids can interfere with the pathological interpretation of biopsy, which should be done before empiric testing.

D) INCORRECT:

A PET-CT scan would be a secondary step for a patient in whom malignancy is suspected based on biopsy — for example, when flow cytometry shows a homogeneous lymphocyte population or abnormal cells.

E) INCORRECT:

An antibiotic for coverage of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus would be indicated if the patient had signs of lymphadenitis (e.g., erythema, fluctuance, tenderness) that were unresponsive to the initial broad-spectrum antibiotic.
